body.p: Couchbase Server 4.6 (Developer Preview) delivers some exciting capabilities for cross datacenter replication, security, query, tools, and application development. Take a look at What's new for a list of new features and improvements that are available in this release.

section.title: Changes in Behavior
section.p:
Here are the behavior changes in the product, compared to the previous release:
Creating a primary index for queries.
In version 4.5 and earlier releases, when you try to execute a query and no matching index exists, the message "No primary index found. Create primary index" is returned. Starting version 4.6, the following error message with "code: 4000" is returned: "No index available on keyspace default that matches your query. Use CREATE INDEX or CREATE PRIMARY INDEX to create an index, or check that your expected index is online."

row.entry: Clock drift alert messages shows up incorrectly even when NTP is properly configured.
When you cancel a query from the workbench, the query continues to run on the server even though the UI indicates that it was canceled.
Upgrading query nodes to 4.5 can cause the 4.0 index service to crash during rolling upgrade (stale=false).
Mac OSX 10.12 Sierra requires Go 1.7.1 or greater.

Breaking Change. FTS index definitions from earlier releases no longer work due to the removal of byte_array_converter. As a workaround, you must manually remove the “byte_array_converter” attribute from the index definition JSON and then recreate the index.

MossStore is now the default kv store for FTS. If you have full text index definitions from previous versions that you want to update, change “kvStoreName” to “mossStore”, otherwise they will stay set to “forestdb”.

section.title: Deprecated Features
section.p:
Support for the following platforms is deprecated in this release:
Microsoft Windows 2008
Microsoft Windows 2008 R2 SP1
Ubuntu 12.0.4
Mac OSX 10.10
The following functionality is deprecated, will be deprecated or is unsupported.

row.entry: META() is used in CREATE INDEX statements, and in queries with only one term (no JOIN or NEST). It helps disambiguate when there are multiple terms due to JOIN and NEST. However, this requirement is not enforced, and META() is still accepted and generally refers to the first term. In future releases, this ambiguity may not be supported when there are multiple terms.
